item.title: Fund Students Not Systems – Ep.192 – Jeff Park From The Anarchist Bible Study – Part 2
item.description:
Fund Students Not Systems

Homeschool, private, public, or any other school parent in between should check out and support those groups with the mantra of “Fund Students Not Systems”. Policy expert, Jeff Park (Alberta Parents’ Union & Co-Host of The Anarchist Bible Study) joins me in the second half of the interview.

In this section, we talk about combatting woke education especially if you’re a Christian parent. What is the best and most Christian way of addressing issues you find in your child’s education? Then we talk about the public policy push popularized by Corey DeAngelis to fund students not systems. It helps parents from every educational choice and every economic status. We then talk about what a decentralized school funding operation would look like.

Ultimately, everything comes down to your responsibility as parents to educate your children as directed to and gifted to by God.

item.title: The Christian Responsibility To Educate Children – Ep.191 – Jeff Park From The Anarchist Bible Study – Part 1
item.description:
The Christian Responsibility To Educate Children

Is it the Christian responsibility to educate children or is it fine leaving that to the so-called experts? While the answer may seem simple enough, we invited an expert on public policy in education and Christian podcaster Jeff Park. He talks about the Christian’s responsibility in educating one’s children and where the responsibility lies. He goes over the current educational landscape (in both the United States and Canada). Finally, we discuss the rise of homeschooling and the benefits for both parents and adults – and why not always having a teaching degree isn’t a bad thing. This is part one of our discussion.

item.title: Church History Matters – Ep.189 – Troy Fraiser From Revived Thoughts Interview – Part 1
item.description:
Church History Matters

This week I’m joined by THE Troy Fraiser who is one part of the Revived Studio/Revived Thoughts podcast empire. He joins me to discuss why Church history matters and what we can learn from it. What does this have to do with apologetics? The past 2,000 years of the church have been nothing but an apologetic to who God is and what His People, the Church, do in history!

Because Troy is so knowledgeable on the subject the interview HAD to be split up into two parts. In this first part, we talk about what is interesting enough about church history to dedicate a show to it. We talk about the sung and unsung heroes in brief. Then we talk about what church history is and who should be included. Finally, we talk about the pride we should have in a God who moves people to do what the great cloud of witnesses to the faith has done to get us to where we are today – and how we should learn from them so we can grow and go and not shrink and dink – around.

Next week is part 2 with even more goodness in store. Check the links below!

item.title: Take Every Thought Captive – Ep.188 – Against All Opposition – Reasoning As A Christian Should
item.description:
Take Every Thought Captive

The Christian is commanded to take every thought to obey Christ (2 Corinthians 10:5). It’s not just in the realm of morality or on Sundays. It doesn’t involve just the personal thoughts or the public actions. Every thought is to be conformed to the sovereignty of God. Even our apologetics? Even our starting points for how we view facts? Every. Thought.

Of course this is easier said than done and even the Apostle Paul knew that. It’s why it’s called a sanctification process and not a moment. How we interact with the brute facts of this world and those messages that entice us away from God’s path are to be responded in the biblical way. We are to be corrected by the Word of God especially if we find ourselves to have a wrong intrepretation of God’s Word. We are called to live rightly by democracy rule. God is a monarchy and we are called to serve the King as sons and daughters.

As we are demolishing arguments and every lofty opinion raised against the knowledge of God, let us always seek to obey Christ.

item.title: Facts Don’t Change Hearts – Ep.187 – Against All Opposition – Foundational Faith
item.description:
Facts Don’t Change Hearts

What do you mean facts don’t change hearts? You just build up enough facts on top of someone they can’t help but change their minds. While that might be true of some low investment beliefs think about something like the abortion debate. Does talking about the science of human life at conception and the different DNA between mother and child convince the other side that the murder is wrong? Not even medical doctors change their minds with their beliefs on that subject. So while you may be able to convince someone that Jesus existed or that he was looked up to as a leader and teacher, pushing them over the edge to believing that He died to save you from your sins is something that would so oppose their underlying belief system that moving them from that spot would be difficult – one could even say it would take an act of God to accomplish.

So we look at the relationship facts and faith play in a person’s worldview and show while facts are not to be fully dismissed they aren’t always the kill shot we’re looking for. Human nature doesn’t work that way. And greater still – it’s exactly what The Bible tells us to expect.

item.title: The War Between Faiths – Ep.186 – Against All Opposition – It’s Impossible To Think Without Presuppositions – Part 2
item.description:
The War Between Faiths

Listen you illogical Christian, we can talk about if God exists but you have to not rely on your ultimate standard or any scholar who is a Christian. You can’t rely on anyone philosopher older than 20 years ago because they’ve all been proven wrong and you definitely can’t rely on anything in your Bible. Oh, also I can use science, reason, logic, trusting of my senses, and the morality I subscribe to and no I don’t have to prove it. There – now we’re on neutral ground. And go. – – – This isn’t a war between faith and science; it’s the war between faiths.

item.title: Where Everyone Starts Thinking – Ep.185 – Against All Opposition – It’s Impossible To Think Without Presuppositions – Part 1
item.description:
Where Everyone Starts Thinking

Give me just the facts and only then will I believe. No. No. Not those facts I don’t like those facts! The idea that one starts with zero assumptions and believes ideas based on just the facts is nice thinking but it’s not how people think. Where everyone starts thinking is through their presuppositions – the starting point where one filters the facts through.

It’s inescapable and we delude ourselves in thinking it’s different. We want to believe we are Spock that divorces himself from emotion and only accepts the logic of the situation. But wait – logic? In a purely natural world that has no transcendental Mind, how is logic to be trusted or even thought of as real? Plus, just logic is not how humans think.

Everyone has a place for faith and it starts with those ideas that they first bring to the table and are really hard to change. Because they inform how one thinks about the complete scope of all reality.

Jim, we’re human not a Vulcan philosopher!

item.title: All Have Faith In Their Reasons – Ep.184 – Against All Opposition – Faith Or Reason?
item.description:
All Have Faith In Their Reasons

The fight of the 20th century, folks! Who will win in the the two giants in their field? Will it be Faith which seems to be slowing down from its prime? Or is it Reason; the newcomer who claims to be the unfeeling, unemotional piece of iron? There can only be one winner! Well, uh actually, when it comes down to it everyone has faith in their reasons. The real question is, what worldview supports and allows for reason to take place?

We begin the first chapter of our book looking at the alleged fight between faith and reason. Properly defining the terms is always a key issue and interacting with the claims for some who have a caricature of what faith really is or what Christianity really claims shows how lacking the conversation can be right off the bat. Christians and those wanting to co-op the religion haven’t always done us the best favors with this at times. But today is the day and this episode is the episode where you can subvert all those “nice Christians” on TV who aren’t real and don’t show real Christianity.

Let the world think we’re foolish but let’s not actively give them a true reason.

At the start of this book is the answer to what’s at the center of every worldview. It’s not the end conclusion we need to begin with. It’s the before we start parts that are important. item.title: Why? For God’s Glory! – Ep.181 – Scott Christensen Interview On What About Evil – Part 2
item.description:
Why? For God’s Glory!

Scott Christensen has written an amazing book that is not just a dry, academic look at the question of why evil exists. Why? For God’s Glory! Pastor Christensen joins us to talk about his Greater-Glory Theodicy that places God at the center of the picture of the ultimate story of reality.

We then ask Pastor Christensen a pastoral question to help us Christians offer hope to those who experience evil. Even in the life of non-believers, we see one of the biggest emotional questions is why is this evil happening. Pastor Christensen gives an amazing answer that points us to the Creator and Sustainer of all things and ultimately to Christ on the Cross.

Thanks again to Scott Christensen for his work and for coming back on the show.

item.itunes:title: Why? For God's Glory! - Ep.181 - Scott Christensen Interview On What About Evil - Part 2

item.title: Free Will Theodicy Failure – Ep.180 – Scott Christensen Interview On What About Evil – Part 1
item.description:
Free Will Theodicy Failures

We have the pleasure of welcoming back to the show our first guest, our first returning guest, and author of the book we recently finished “What About Evil? A Defense of God’s Sovereign Glory” – Pastor Scott Christensen. This was such a great discussion we wanted to break it up into two different parts. In the first part of the interview, we discuss what a theodicy is and what some of the free will theodicy failures are from one of the more cited explanations for why evil exists.

Scott Christensen kindly sets up the stage for what the question is that his book covers and we jump right into the discussion. This will lead us right into the discussion for next week where we pick back up to talk about if not the free will theodicy with all its issues – what’s the theodicy that best puts God – and man, in their proper place?

item.title: The Greater Glory Effect – Ep.179 – What About Evil? – The Grace And Glory Effect – Part 2
item.description:
The Greater Glory Effect

And now comes the end. The Great-Glory Theodicy showcases the greater glory effect. It is seen in the forgiving nature of the Christian as it reflects the forgiving nature of God. Even the worse of humanity, the most painful, the most destructive nature of man is no match for the grace that is unmerited but much needed.

We provide an overview of the book that we just read with you to hit those points of the theodicy that Scott Christensen believes not only best explains evil but is also the most biblical explanation. We wrap up with a personal review and a hope that you came away at least challenged but at best moved to greater knowledge and glorifying nature of who God is and what He has done.

Thank you to Scott Christensen for his book and thank you for joining us in reading What About Evil? A Defense of God’s Sovereign Glory. We hope to see you for our next book that we swore we would read one day – and in it – give God the glory.

item.title: How Should We Then Live? – Ep.178 – What About Evil? – The Grace And Glory Effect – Part 1
item.description:
How Should We Then Live?

We live in a world infested with evil. We live in a world held in the sovereign hand of God. How should we then live?

The Christian life is one led in a moment of three simultaneous instances of sight. We look back on our lives that were in rebellion against God. That life heaped evil onto the world as it was led in direct opposition to who God is and His Will. We look at our current lives that are justified by Christ’s work on the Cross and walk in the sanctification path to conform our lives to God’s Will. We look forward to the time of the end when every tear will be wiped away and where death and evil will have their final defeat.

How should we then live? We should live as those who forgive much because we were forgiven much. We should live as those who show mercy because we were shown mercy. We should live as those who face the horrors of this world we stand up and willingly give of ourselves because Jesus Christ was the main example. And as we took part in His suffering, we now take part in bestowing mercy upon others – even if those that suffer are victims of the Holocaust; even if those that suffer in the Holocaust are there because of their Christian act of mercy.

How should we then live? We should live like Christ lived and overcome evil.

item.title: The Coming Redeemer – Ep.177 – What About Evil? – The Cosmic Redeemer – Part 2
item.description:
The Coming Redeemer

No, we’re not doing The Return Of The King, but we are looking forward to the end of this book as we are looking forward to the end of The Book of the Coming Redeemer. These books will have a single ending unlike a certain 3rd movie you might be thinking about.

In this section we look at Christ coming back and what He brings with respect to dealing with evil. The redemption that takes place is the result of the King returning and glorifying everything more than it has ever been – even before the Fall. We also look at why salvation isn’t most people or no people at all. A strong theodicy should be able to account for that. Finally, we cover the question of why things like God’s Law and Satan were allowed into the world and continue to exist till the end.

There are no eagles in this book but we are coming to the end.

item.title: The Resurrection Explained! – Ep.176 – What About Evil? – The Cosmic Redeemer – Part 1
item.description:
The Resurrection Explained!

Why was the end of the Incarnation of Jesus on Earth important? What does it mean to people before, during, and after the Cross? How does the Resurrection ensure a believer’s redemption? Well, this is the first part of the Resurrection explained! What does it all mean? Everything!

With the Resurrection of Jesus, His ascension into Heaven puts a pin in His coming again. Where He was first the lamb slain as the suffering servant His next appearance will be as the conquering King. But before we get to the end, we need to look at what’s next after the empty tomb.

We have to see what the Resurrection does in context of Satan and sin. Are they defeated or is there a future end? What are the benefits of the Resurrection? Well, we see the benefits in areas of a Christian’s justification, sanctification, and glorification. These are shared experiences between believers across the gulf of history. These experiences are for those who surround us right now and are a part of what we build as being fellow heirs in the Kingdom of God.

Aslan is coming and the sons and daughters of men must make ready for the final battle.

item.title: The Suffering Redeemer – Ep.175 – What About Evil? – The Suffering Redeemer – Part 2
item.description:
The Suffering Redeemer

The Christian story emphasizes a focus on the suffering of Jesus Christ. He is our suffering Redeemer. Being born, living in the ancient Near East, being hungry and poor, and ultimately being nailed on a cross illegally as the most innocent person ever involves suffering. Not only does this not seem to surprise Jesus but it seems to be a necessary component God uses to bring about the defeat of evil.

Suffering serves a function in the Incarnation and that suffering was a necessity in the life of the Messiah. Showing the need of truly understanding the seriousness of sin shows just how important, serious, and terror-inducing having the divine wrath of God poured out on sin is. We also look at if suffering happens in the Trinity as a result of the Incarnation. All this leads up to the completion point of why the Suffering Redeemer had to come in the manner He did for the purpose He did and in a way that makes our theodicy matter.

Timeline:

20:52 – Tetelestai!
26:22 – Conclusion

item.title: Does God Have Emotions? – Ep.174 – What About Evil? – The Suffering Redeemer – Part 1
item.description:
Does God Have Emotions?

When we talk about Jesus as God and as the Suffering Servant the question of, “Does God have emotions?” is to be asked. Is God able to have emotions like us humans? Is He surprised at the evil He sees in the world? Is prophecy, then, just a lucky guess by God?

While some of those answers seem obvious, we should make sure we are communicating them thoroughly enough to present the orthodox response that is accurate to the revealed Scriptures and that covers the questions we should expect as a follow-up.

In the Incarnation we see Jesus suffer. It’s a main part of the story. Can God suffer? How about this question – can God die? The knee-jerk responses are there but are they good enough to stand up to a Muslim apologist or an open theist? Do we know the God we claim to know well enough to understand this very important part and how important it is in our theodicy?

We cover this shorter chapter in two parts to make sure we (mostly Patrick) get a better grasp on it.

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction

08:42 – Divine Impassibility

17:58 – God’s Affections Are Like Our & Also Not
20:52 – God Can’t Have Sinful Emotions
22:49 – Divine Compassion & Eradication Of Suffering
25:49 – Conclusion

item.title: Fully Man & Fully God – Ep.173 – What About Evil? – The Peerless Redeemer – Part 2
item.description:
Fully Man & Fully God

Jesus not only is fully man & fully God but He must be both in that full capacity to accomplish everything He must for our salvation. To deny His humanity is to not have a stand-in for humanity. To deny His Godhood is to not have the ability to pay the penalty for all His Sheep and to be able to take on the wrath of God.

In The Bible, we see the regular way that Jesus operates. Yes, with signs and miracles and wonders but as a man. And yet, the universe still operates, and all things that were made by Him and held together by Him still go round and round. In His Earthly work, He is obedient to the Law, He fully justifies, and He is fully righteous. He is tempted in a way that others would fail and in that temptation God experiences the direct knowledge of suffering and temptation. And yet, He does not sin. He redeems us but He is our sympathetic Redeemer!

item.title: Why The Incarnation Had To Happen – Ep.172 – What About Evil? – The Peerless Redeemer – Part 1
item.description:
Why The Incarnation Had To Happen

The Greater-Glory Theodicy centers on the character of who God is and the reasons He has in glorifying Himself in a world of evil. With that in mind, why the incarnation had to happen was to uniquely and completely deal with all the evil in full.

Once Christians were able to sit down amongst themselves they worked on clarifying and systematizing what The Bible says about the Incarnation. At the Council of Chalcedon, orthodoxy was recognized. The Incarnation is a difficult concept to grasp because it is a unique event and the information we are provided is found in the consistent words of Scripture and what is known about who God is.

God deals with sin in a mysterious, paradoxical, and unusual way – just the way we would expect a transcendent God to do! Even the nihilist Albert Camus sees the importance and benefit that Incarnation provides.

If the ending seems very abrupt it’s because we so much enjoyed this chapter that we kept going and forgot to split it into two parts. Check back next week for an abrupt beginning and the completion of this amazing chapter.

20:00 – Why God Had To Be Incarnate

item.title: Romans 9 Answers Why Evil Exists – Ep.171 – What About Evil? – God’s Redemptive Glory In Scripture – Part 2
item.description:
Romans 9 Answers Why Evil Exists

The promised chapter on how Romans 9 answers why evil exists is here! Continuing from our look at the Old Testament we look at Paul’s answer to why there exists evil and how God uses it for His glory.

We are unable to divorce ourselves from the Old Testament and Paul engages with a question of what is God’s purpose in choosing some and not others especially if some not chosen are not the “chosen people of God”. We actually do see God’s chosen people but they are made up of both Jew & Gentile. But is there something special about those God chosen for salvation and/or something badly special about those God doesn’t choose. Romans 9 says that the exact answer of why evil exists. For God’s redemptive glory as seen in Scripture.

item.title: God Redeeming Evil In The Old Testament – Ep.170 – What About Evil? – God’s Redemptive Glory In Scripture – Part 1
item.description:
Redeeming Evil In The Old Testament

One of the goals of the Greater-Glory Theodicy is to find not just the best logical explanation for why evil exists. It is also to see if the special revelation of God details its reason. In this episode we look at how is God redeeming evil in the Old Testament.

Evil is not a whispered result of sin. From chapter 3 of Genesis and moving forward throughout the entirety of the Old Testament you couldn’t swing a donkey’s jawbone without running into a story of evil. Why? In those stories, God is redeeming that evil for His purposes, for future redemption, for ultimate removal, and for the pinnacle of human history – the Incarnation of Jesus Christ.

Let us look at the Old Testament and see the glory that God receives becomes greater and manifested to His creation because evil is present – and being dealt with.

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
01:54 – Dealing With Evil In Unexpected Ways
05:07 – God’s Redemption In The Fall

item.title: Christianity, Sci-Fi, & Indie Publishing – Ep.169 – Katie Roome From Periapsis Press Interview
item.description:
Christianity, Sci-Fi, & Indie Publishing

We are joined today by Katie Roome who is the founder and writer of Periapsis Press. We sit down and talk about Christianity, sci-fi, & indie publishing. Is there a difference between the genres; and what do they tell us about God’s story and humanity? So we’re talking nerdy today!

Periapsis Press offers long-form, positive reviews for independent authors in the science fiction and fantasy genre. While not every book is “Christian fiction” the books’ themes and values “do not come in conflict with our Christian worldview”.

We discuss the importance of reading things through the lens of a Christian worldview and why sci-fi and fantasy are great avenues to explore the ultimate story of God and our place in it. We, of course, have to talk about how bad Christian fiction is – and indie fiction as well. However, Periapsis Press is a place to show that’s not always the case and in the struggles of indie authors, there are positives. We also talk about how to be a good reader and reviewer. And book recommendations!

Here’s the spot where I usually list the nerd references. Ya, that’s just the whole episode.

Timeline:

item.title: Was The Fall Necessary? – Ep.168 – What About Evil? – The Fortunate Fall & God’s Greatest Glory – Part 3
item.description:
Was The Fall Necessary?

One of the biggest questions that comes from the Greater-Glory Theodicy is this – Was The Fall necessary? Because that’s what it seems to imply. Well, that’s actually what it comes right out and says. It’s nothing to blush at or be embarrassed about. It’s the necessary outcome for God’s purposes.

To focus on the negative, however, is to miss the “glory” of the Greater-Glory Theodicy. In this episode, we cover four of them and cover what is the purpose of evil as it relates to magnifying and displaying God’s glory more fully than if The Fall never occurred.

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
01:05 – Was The Fall Necessary?
05:33 – A Better, Best-Of-All-Possible Worlds Theory
08:44 – 4 Hopes Of The Greater-Glory Theodicy
11:00 – 1) Christ Bears Our Sins
12:43 – 2) Christ Bears Our Sorrows
14:35 – 3) Focus On Future Glory
17:07 – 4) Raising The Banner Of Divine Grace
17:58 – Evil Allows God To Display His Glory More Fully
22:49 – Conclusion

item.title: God’s Glory Seen In Evil – Ep.167 – What About Evil? – The Fortunate Fall & God’s Greatest Glory – Part 2
item.description:
God’s Glory Seen In Evil

Now that we’ve laid out the Greater-Glory Theodicy that Scott Christensen has presented we unpack what it actually does that others don’t. In this theodicy, God’s Glory seen in evil is established. This doesn’t come from a novel, clever way to get around popular theories. This comes from the overall presentation of Scripture of who God is and what His greatest desire is.

What’s God’s purpose for creating the universe and all life including human life? What’s God’s purpose for revealing who He is through direct revelation to His image-bearers? What is the purpose of Christ’s incarnation and atonement? It is the same reason why God allows evil into the world.

item.title: The Greater-Glory Theodicy – Ep.166 – What About Evil? – The Fortunate Fall & God’s Greatest Glory – Part 1
item.description:
The Greater-Glory Theodicy

We’ve knocked down the standard explanations. We’ve established who God is and what He desires. We’ve told His story in history from a story tale. Now, we get to tackle what Scott Christensen believes is the best explanation for evil with all those elements put together – The Greater-Glory Theodicy.

In this episode, we break down the three premises and conclusion of the Greater-Glory Theodicy and see that the conclusion is supported by them. From there we begin to cover some of the details embedded in the argument. One of them being is to figure out whether or not God is required to save anyone by giving His Grace to them.

Join us on our quest for a biblically-based theodicy.

item.title: God’s Purpose With Evil – Ep.165 – What About Evil? – The One True Story – Part 2
item.description:
God’s Purpose With Evil

After setting the scene with Creation and The Fall, we are now able to see what God’s purpose with evil is. Following the story paradigm, we see God’s story played out in the rising action, climax, falling action, and denouement. Each part covers an evil plot point where God is able to reveal Himself more fully to His creation.

Throughout God’s story of redemption, we see a repeated pattern of man attempting to cover his sin on his own or go his own way. Ultimately, and every time, he fails. Fortunately, God comes in and provides a much better and fuller way. This goes from Adam through the Jewish nation and culminates at the person and ministry of Jesus Christ. He comes, conquers, and rules in such a way that the twists and turns makes the story that much more compelling.

And the application point is that within the story which contains evil, God is in complete control AND He uses His creation in His relation to them to carry out His victory and removal of evil. His Kingdom will reign over all creation – even of Mars.

Timeline:

20:18 – Falling Action – Ascension & Ruling
21:38 – Evil Won’t Go Without A Fight
24:18 – Denouement – The Better Kingdom Established, Paradise Restored
26:14 – Could The Story Be Good Without Evil?
29:40 – Conclusion

item.title: Evil’s Purpose In God’s Story – Ep.164 – What About Evil? – The One True Story – Part 1
item.description:
Evil’s Purpose In God’s Story

What is evil’s purpose in God’s story? To begin to understand the answer we look at the fact that God’s written story, The Bible, is more than just propositions and commands – it is also stories.

As it is the first story by the original Author we can call it a monomyth. This isn’t myth like Greek or Roman myths. It differs in many ways and in this episode we cover those differences. The historical declarations made at specific times and places along with the purpose of the stories and how they are told make God’s story different than pagan myths.

From there we begin unfolding God’s story so that we can understand evil’s purpose in God’s story. In the beginning God. Then He builds the set. Then He casts His cast and crew. Then the conflict is quickly introduced and the villain emerges!

And the shirt Patrick is wearing? It’s only The War Of The Worlds printed in its entirety on it. What a story that includes an evil conflict!

item.title: The Structure Of God’s Story – Ep.163 – What About Evil? – Everyone Loves A Good Ending – Part 2
item.description:
The Structure Of God’s Story

Now that we looked at what myths are and what the monomyth of God’s story is; we look at what the structure of God’s story is – as well as all other stories follow. The shared collective consciousness of humanity reflects what it cannot help – the reflection of their Creator who is a Storyteller in their structure and desire to tell stories.

Looking at Freytag’s Pyramid of storytelling we see the five parts of a story all myths and important stories take on. Seeing either comedy or tragedy, the end goal is to convey an important concept or cultural value in the end.

We give a lot of examples from movies and book genres to show that our stories can be tied right back to our Creator. We create because He creates. We teach how He teaches. And evil has a place in the story and teaching.

item.title: God As The Monomyth Storyteller – Ep.162 – What About Evil? – Everyone Loves A Good Ending – Part 1
item.description:
God As The Monomyth Storyteller

The term “myth” has a colloquial understanding of being made up or fake. But that’s not the true meaning of the word. Myths are stories told in a worldview used to relay information to a group and that story is made to stick. This universal concept derives itself from God. God as the monomyth Storyteller sets up our theodicy to explain why evil exists.

Looking at societies and tribes and even families and neighborhoods, humanity to a source of storytellers. We have more books today than at any other point in time because we have not yet run out of stories to tell. Science fiction informs our ideas of the future while relating to the reader of today. Fantasy gives us tales of adventure and mystery with the spice of magic. Even our factual based stories of war and politics are not told in a mundane way. The facts are accompanied with hopefully a good story. Taking the fun out of history is the job of schools.

Man is a storyteller by nature. With the Christian worldview, we know that we get our nature from God. In God’s communicative character, we find Him as our ultimate Storyteller. And in His story, there are bad guys and evil afoot.

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
01:53 – Stories Are Primal For Man – And God
10:38 – The Truth Of Mythic Stories
18:43 – True Myths
22:22 – The Emerging Monomyth
29:04 – Conclusion

item.title: How To Bring Apologetics Into The Church – Ep.161 – Question & Answer
item.description:
How To Bring Apologetics Into The Church

In this episode, we responds to a great listener question about how to bring apologetics into the church. The question is specifically from a pastor’s point of view but we answer it in a way to be useful for the pastor, elder, deacon, Christian teacher, or layperson to be useful to his/her local church and build up the body of Christ.

With all the things the church needs to address – sound doctrine, exegesis, sanctification/morality, etc. it can feel a little overwhelming for pastors to hear about things like apologetics or textual criticism or church history and be told that “the Church needs to cover these topics as well”. What if that pastor or teacher or layperson doesn’t feel particularly equipped to deal with those things especially on top of all the other responsibilities?

Is the only response to make a general suggestion to the congregation that they can read about it in books about apologetics? Do you want to direct your people to random YouTube searches? Or what about people who don’t think they need to hear about these topics?

Well here’s a random YouTube show who encourages you to read books about apologetics especially for those who may not be interested in the depth of the topic – to provide their answer.

item.title: God’s Responsibility In The Fall – Ep.160 – What About Evil? – The Challenge Of Moral Responsibility – Part 2
item.description:
God’s Responsibility In The Fall

Continuing to look at God’s responsibility when it comes to evil, we look at God’s responsibility in the Fall of mankind. Both sides of the choice debate have to recognize the Fall as something unique and comes with their own set of questions. Which side is the most consistent AND the most biblical?

Genesis 50 offers up one of the best biblical views of divine determinism as well as the moral responsibility of man for evil alone but God’s decree of that same evil. Evil does not exist independently from God. God is not reacting to evil. God is not surprised by evil. God is not being forced to deal with evil. There is no conflict in determinism when approached fairly.

Then we look at the Fall and see that Adam and Eve seem to offer up a special case and because of the limits to the metaphysical nature of man pre-Fall, we come up with a mystery. With all that being said, we still see that God is still sovereign in the Fall. It was not an accident and it was not God being a puppet master and forcing Adam & Eve to sin.

This chapter is really preparing the way for Christensen to present his own theodicy that incorporates all the issues he’s presented so far along with the biblical narrative truth God provided.

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
03:22 – God Decrees Evil But Is Not Morally Responsible
04:51 – Joseph & His Brothers As The Best Example
07:05 – Evil Does Not Exist Independent Of God
08:10 – No Conflict With Determinism
10:20 – The Biggest Problem – The Fall Of Man
15:19 – Adam & Eve Were Not Puppets
17:22 – God Is Still Sovereign In The Fall Into Sin
23:05 – Was God The Direct Cause Of The First Sin? No.
25:57 – The Fall Was Not An Accident
29:40 – Conclusion

item.title: God Is Free Of Evil – Ep.159 – What About Evil? – The Challenge Of Moral Responsibility – Part 1
item.description:
God Is Free Of Evil

God is free of evil because of who He is and His transcendence over His creation. But is He still considered the “author of evil”?

Looking at people like the authors of the Westminster Confessions, Jonathan Edwards, and John Frame we see the Reformed tradition is not caught off guard by this claim that results in recognizing God’s complete sovereignty over all things – including evil. Good analogies exist to show the clarity of this paradox as long as we recognize that all analogies break down.

We look at what God’s transcendence, intentions, decrees, and knowledge allows Him to decree evil while not being evil Himself or His actions be evil. God is responsible for all things but those responsibilities can be deficient in cause. In similar fashion, God’s commands that man ought to do something (or not do something) might seem to need an allowance in an ability to do/not do those things but that’s a misunderstanding of the ought/can distinction.

God is good because of His nature and standing above His creation. Man, as His creatures, are not good because of his nature and standing in God’s creation.

item.title: God’s Work In Evil – Ep.158 – What About Evil? – Walking Through The Bible’s Dark Forest – Part 2
item.description:
God’s Work In Evil

Now that we’ve established the character and nature of God and seen that The Bible doesn’t shy away from attributing God’s control to evil actions of humans, we look at two other aspects of evil The Bible talks about.

In divine hardening, we see that God steers the desires of humans to accomplish His will and His plans. We see it with kings and groups of people and individuals. The biggest example is Pharaoh in the Old Testament. But also seen in Romans 1 with those who suppress the knowledge of God. On the opposite end, God restrains evil humanity from being as evil as we could be. The nature of man is set in evil and there’s no divine need to force a choice to do evil. Just the opposite, for any good to occur God must be the first cause.

We, of course, have to look at the biggest example of evil and see that God is in control. Not just of the individual actions and decisions that lead to the culmination of God’s plan of redemption but in every single action, life, and continuation of life to get everything and everyone at that moment. It would take some all-powerful divine Being to orchestrate such a thing! Well, do I have a Book for you!

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
01:26 – Divine Hardening & Evil
04:32 – Pharaoh & Divine Hardening

15:28 – The Decree Of Evil Consistent With The Nature Of God
19:42 – God’s Good In The Greatest Evil To Ever Happen
24:45 – Is God Morally Culpable For Evil?

item.title: Is God The Author Of Evil? – Ep.157 – What About Evil? – Walking Through The Bible’s Dark Forest – Part 1
item.description:
Is God The Author Of Evil?

Is God the author of evil? That’s the question that Reformed Christians must be able to answer especially after dismantling libertarian free will. Here we begin to look at the characteristics God embodies that informs the discussion of his sovereignty over evil.

Looking at God’s absolute goodness and holiness and righteousness, we have to realize God is not made up of parts and these qualities are embodied in God fully and completely but also in a perfect balance of each other. This can then inform our understanding of God’s sovereignty over all creation including the good – and the evil.

We look at what The Bible has to say about God actually being tied to evil – but seen in the correct outlook. However, this outlook is shied away from by academics and scholars in a pious but improper manner. Looking at one of the biggest examples of this is from the book of Job.

item.title: What About Compatibilism? – Ep. 156 – What About Evil? – The Transcendent Author Of History – Part 2
item.description:
What About Compatibilism?

We delve into the topic of God’s choosing and man’s choosing as it relates to evil. If you’ve ever wondered, “What about compatibilism? What is it and is it true?” this episode will break down the concept for you.

First, we finish up the last two secondary characteristics that stem from God’s transcendent nature. One is God taking action in His Providence. This just isn’t in the miracles or the big events from history but also in the boring and mundane details. Also, we see God’s unrestricted use of His power in His omnipotence. Then we look at the compatible nature of God as creator and man as creature. We see how important both God’s nature and man’s nature limits each in what is able to be chosen. Here highlights the vast difference between God and man but still a relationship and moral culpability.

We hope these breakdowns are beneficial to you and thank you for joining us as we cover topics like this to learn more and to honor and glorify the Lord of Lords.

Timeline:

item.itunes:title: What About Compatibilism? - Ep. 156 - What About Evil? - The Transcendent Author Of History - Part 2

item.title: God Is Transcendent – Ep. 155 – What About Evil? – The Transcendent Author Of History – Part 1
item.description:
God Is Transcendent

Now that we’ve toppled over the main theodicies that have been preeminent in the discussion of evil; we turn back to what should start off any conversation rooted in the Christian worldview – the character and nature of God. Specifically, God is transcendent.

God didn’t just happen upon the universe; He made it from nothing. As such, He is above all and all things that exist and remain because of Him. This is a scary thing for those in rebellion of Him and sadly that is all of humanity. We follow the author as he focuses on the characteristics that follow from God’s transcendent nature. Things like his magnificence, fully incomprehensible nature, and sovereignty are focused on to lay the foundation for the world that exists explicitly because of who God is and His ultimate power.

From that nature, we will see the most complete theodicy arise and that there really is no problem of evil. Just people who have problems with who God is.

Timeline:

item.title: Divine Judgment & Hell – Ep. 154 – What About Evil? – Working For The Greater Good – Part 3
item.description:
Divine Judgment & Hell

Looking at one of the last main theodicies, we look at the topics of divine judgment & Hell. After laying out the argument from the divine-judgment defense we see that while this argument does have some merit to it, it is not an all-encompassing view of evil.

With two interesting problems, it doesn’t seem to deal with the very first evil of the Fall and it doesn’t seem to link evil that is not a direct result of sin. We also see that it doesn’t seem to tie in God’s love and goodness which needs to be in the picture to have a full theodicy picture. Finally, we cover the topic of evil affecting “innocent” people where it seems also appropriate to cover the topic of Hell, damnation, and the fairness of judgment.

While this isn’t a full coverage on the topic of Hell, the need to introduce the topic is done and further reading is offered.

item.title: Soul Making In The Best Possible World – Ep. 153 – What About Evil? – Working For The Greater Good – Part 2
item.description:
Soul-Making In The Best Possible World

Two of the subset theodicies of the Greater-Good Theodicy are the Soul-Making Theodicy and the Best-Of-All-Possible-Worlds Defense. In these, soul-making in the best possible world gives a purpose to evil existing as a means to an end.

From the soul-making side, we see this as a desire in our own stories we share and treasure. Without evil, life is a boring non-story. However, there are some major issues with this theory that involves every non-Christian who ever lived. And from the best possible world, we have a logical idea dependent on the character and nature and God. We see a couple of glaring issues including examples of two worlds that are actually better without evil in it. But we still help Leibniz out with making his work more biblical.

item.title: Greater-Good Theodicy – Ep. 152 – What About Evil? – Working For The Greater Good – Part 1
item.description:
Greater-Good Theodicy – Good From Evil

Looking at another explanation for why there is evil in the world, we turn to the Greater-Good Theodicy. With this, we see a focus on the good that is accomplished as a result of the evil that occurs. From the evil actions of people or evil in the natural world, God is able to produce an abundance of good.

Just as with other theodicies, there are a lot of good things the Greater-Good Theodicy produces and explains. There are also limitations to our creaturely aspect when it comes to always seeing the good from evil. There are several objections this brings up that proponents attempt to explain. Our desire from this idea is that we don’t pursue evil nor do we pursue inaction. Ultimately, the biggest example we can put forward of this theory is the trial, torture, and death of the perfect God-Man, Jesus Christ.

Like the other theories, we’ll look at the issues with this next episode but this explanation does have strengths to support its holding.

Timeline:

item.title: Hermeneutics & Practical Bible Study – Ep. 151 – Josh & Jeff From The Anarchist Bible Study – Part 2
item.description:
Hermeneutics & Practical Bible Study

Continuing our discussion from last week, Jeff and Josh from The Anarchist Bible Study and Patrick talk about how hermeneutics & practical Bible study and how to use each in the other. Hermeneutics isn’t important just for pastors, theologians, and seminaries. It is important for every Christian reading his/her Bible by themselves or in church or in doing apologetics.

In this episode, the guys talk about what to do with different interpretations conflict, or just differ. While not a requirement for understanding, knowing Greek or history deepens your understanding of Scripture. Then we look at practical Bible study tips like how to know what to apply to oneself, how to approach the Bible before opening The Book and how Sola Scriptura plays a part. Then we close with how important this topic is when we do apologetics.

***Note*** – You’ll also have to forgive Jeff’s notifications as he’s super popular at the late hour in which this episode was recorded.

item.title: Hermeneutics & Apologetics – Ep. 150 – Josh & Jeff From The Anarchist Bible Study – Part 1
item.description:
Hermeneutics & Apologetics

Hermeneutics & apologetics go hand-in-hand with each other. Since The Bible is our ultimate standard that it is important that we read it and interpret it the way God meant it to be. And to communicate it to other people accurately is just as important in our apologetics.

Patrick is joined by two amazing guys who are actively showing this important quality of Bible study – Josh & Jeff from The Anarchist Bible Study. On their show, they show the importance of fair and methodical reading of Scripture especially when it comes to exegesis and application.

In this first episode, we go over what hermeneutics is and the importance of understanding the text as the original audience would have understood it. This is important for the average Christian to do and not just the pastor in the pulpit so this is an encouragement and direction to everyone. Josh & Jeff give practical advice from Scripture, logic, and history that will aid you and your witness to the truth of God’s Word as revealed in The Bible.

***Note*** – You’ll also have to forgive Jeff’s notifications as he’s super popular at the late hour in which this episode was recorded.

item.title: Gratuitous Evil, Free Will, & Natural Law – Ep. 149 – What About Evil? – Guarding The Sacred Treasure Of Free Will – Part 4
item.description:
Free Will, Gratuitous Evil, & Natural Law

Free Will, Gratuitous Evil, & Natural Law are all topics that are related in the free-will theodicy.

Free will must deal with the same implications that compatibilists deal with and that’s the appearance of evil without purpose. We look at the different theories free will theists put out to explain those evils and also the troubles those explanations run into.

A close relationship between the free will defense and the natural law defense helps with the other side of evil – evils that occur in nature apart from moral actors (people). This idea that the world must be the way it is in order for humans to be humans seems to run into not just one big, real-world example – but two!

For your sci-fi reference this week we turn to Douglas Adams’ Hitchhiker’s Guide To The Galaxy. Don’t worry, there’s no Vogon poetry. No promises on bad (good) dad jokes.

item.title: Free Will & God’s Foreknowledge – Ep. 148 – What About Evil? – Guarding The Sacred Treasure Of Free Will – Part 3
item.description:
Free Will & God’s Foreknowledge

The concept of free will & God’s foreknowledge can be a heady concept. We attempt to accurately cover three different answers free will advocates attempt to allow God to have foreknowledge (or not have it). We do our best to break it down while attempting to be accurate to supporters and the issues seen with the concepts.

Covering concepts of Arminian simple foreknowledge, open theism, and Molinism & middle knowledge as some of the big attempts to save human freedom; there are still issues with allowing God to be the God revealed in Scripture.

The sci-fi reference this week is Quantum Leap! Oh, boy.

item.title: Problems With Free Will – Ep. 147 – What About Evil? – Guarding The Sacred Treasure Of Free Will – Part 2
item.description:
Problems With Free Will

We continue to look at problems with free will in light of the explanation it supposedly gives Christians when it comes to answering the problem of evil.

We see why the Reformed position rejects parts of libertarian free will in exchange for soft determinism. Libertarian free will undermines the doctrine of depravity, who God is, what Heaven is, who Satan is, and actually seems to undermine the Trinity. On top of that, the presentation of free will in that form seems to make all decisions arbitrary – which seems like a problem.

And of course, there’s a Star Trek V reference. But we don’t answer why God would need a spaceship.

item.title: Do We Have Free Will? – Ep. 146 – What About Evil? – Guarding The Sacred Treasure Of Free Will – Part 1
item.description:
Do We Have Free Will?

The free will defense has done a lot in answering the logical problems of evil. While determinism has become more popular in the past decade among academics; the culture at large still has the embracement of free will. But do we have free will?

We want to ask, “By what standard can we say that we have a will and it is free to do what we wish without interference?” And since we are Christian we want to ultimately appeal to our standard, God’s Word. Do we have the ability to have made alternative choices given the same circumstances? Is man autonomous in his choosing and in his actions?

We want to look at some of the issues of free will and why appealing to an idea that appears to have biblical and logical issues is not the best explanation for why evil exists. We want to be consistent and grounded in an objective truth and reason down from our ultimate standard. Is there a better answer to evil than man just chooses and God has to live with those choices?

Timeline:

00:00 – Introduction
00:53 – What Is Our Grounding For Belief In Anything?
05:30 – All Hail, Free Will!
09:16 – The Natural Law Defense Support With Free Will
10:44 – Libertarian Free Will & Alternative Possible Choices
15:26 – 3 Positives Of Free Will Defense
18:06 – God & Free Will Beings

item.title: Can God Answer Evil? – Ep. 145 – What About Evil? – Justifying The Ways Of God
item.description:
Can God Answer Evil?

Can God answer evil and the problems caused by suffering? That is what a theodicy attempts to do. It provides a justification for why suffering and evil exist and that God exists as presented. This is a reason why one has to stake a claim in a specific God like the biblical, Christian God rather than some generic deity. The consistent worldview that comes from the God of the Bible has a larger set of implications and is more than just a thought experiment dreamed up by a philosopher.

There isn’t just one problem of evil but many including the logical problem, the evidential problem, and the emotional problem. And like we mentioned last episode, it’s not that these problems mean that it defeats the idea of God but that they are issues in need of a solution.

Here we look at how some in the past have found solutions to a problem. We also look at what an answer to the problem of evil, a theodicy, must have in order for the answer to satisfy the questions. And like all good math questions, we must stay in the confines of a specific nature such as the character and revealed nature of who God is.

Timeline:

03:26 – The Logical Problem Of Evil Presented
08:47 – Maybe God Just Isn’t Powerful Enough To Overcome Evil
10:00 – Maybe God Just Isn’t Good Enough To Overcome Evil
11:06 – Maybe God Has Good Reasons To Not Prevent All Evil
13:17 – Alvin Plantinga Destroys The Logical Problem Of Evil
15:11 – The Evidential Problem Of Evil Presented
16:30 – Is There So Much Big Evil That Shows There Is No God?
18:02 – The Emotional Problem Of Evil Presented
20:44 – Is A Theodicy Still Possible?
23:08 – Two Criteria A Theodicy Must Have
24:31 – All Evil Must Have A Good Reason To Exist
28:16 – All The Good Accomplished Must Be Worth It
29:51 – Theodicy Vs. A Defense
36:12 – Conclusion

item.title: The Battle Of Two Moral Standards – Ep. 144 – What About Evil? – Probing The Darkness – Part 2
item.description:
The Battle Of Two Moral Standards

After finishing with defining our terms we look at ways in which those definitions play out in our worldviews. Here’s where the battle of two moral standards starts to interact and separate. Each side has a burden of proof since each side has a problem of evil.

Where the secular side wants to tout a focus on human flourishing, we look at a standard which isn’t grounded and a hard target to hit. We also look at the two strings of conclusions that stem from the secular worldview when it comes to morality. Either, morals are an illusion (moral nihilism) or there are objective moral standards in the world (moral realism). Which version has the better accounting of reality? And which side has the ability to ground their ideas in an objective way – if that is even possible?

We didn’t cover everything in this chapter and it’s why you should pick up the book and check out the ideas presented. Links below.

item.title: Defining Evil – Ep. 143 – What About Evil? – Probing The Darkness – Part 1
item.description:
Defining Evil

Definitions are one of the most important parts of having any conversation. A lot of times people use different definitions as a result of their worldview. So when it comes to the topic of evil, defining evil is vital.

In this chapter, we look at a secular version as well as the Christian definition of evil. This highlights the divide between the different worldviews and shows the need for proper grounding in an objective, transcendent standard.

We also take a look at the importance of God as that standard and why things could be designated as one of two types of evil we see in the world – and seen by both the secularist and the Christian alike.

item.title: Crisis Of Secularism – Ep. 142 – What About Evil? – Theodicy And The Crisis Of Our Secular Age – Part 2
item.description:
Crisis Of Secularism

Picking up where we left off last time; now that the world has shirked off God because of the evil all we are left now with is us and evil. Ut oh. We are in a crisis of secularism.

The second part of the modern worldview is the advancing of secularism leading to the unavoidable cliff of Niechzte’s nihilism. Since we have not advanced in a further explanation of life’s meaning other than personal desires we are now running up against the borrowed benefits of the Christian worldview results.

Today, we have it much easier than people did in 1755 and yet we find ourselves some of the most volatile, self-medicated, and unbalanced people. When it comes to things like death, violence, and suffering our self-actualized reality and saving devices don’t seem to be doing us any good.

However, there is still a source for an explanation of a theodicy – for the problem of evil.

item.title: The Enlightenment And Evil – Ep. 141 – What About Evil? – Theodicy And The Crisis Of Our Secular Age – Part 1
item.description:
The Enlightenment And Evil

We ended up going long on this chapter and so we split it up into two episodes so there is a hard cut and no outro at the end of this episode. There’s a lot to cover with the Enlightenment and evil.

Where did the problem of evil really become a problem? Scott Christensen does a marvelous job in this chapter (one of my favorites) in presenting the Enlightenment era kickoff of questioning evil’s place in God’s world and traces it forward to the modern worldview.

Evil just didn’t spring into existence in 1755, but the events of the day and the psyche of the Western world presented the best melting pot to not just ask the questions but throw off the conventions of dealing with evil in theory and in practice. The next episode will show the ramifications of such decisions.

We don’t cover everything in this chapter but it is a great read. We do get some alternative history and space talk in here so the nerdy streak is kept alive.

item.title: What About Evil Summary – Ep. 140 – What About Evil? – Introduction – Part 2
item.description:
What About Evil Summary

Along with the answer to the question, “What about evil?”, at the beginning of the book; Scott Christensen also gives us a What About Evil summary of the book too. Here is the chapter-by-chapter breakdown of the book with just a small take on what’s included.

Within the book, we get a history lesson is why and when humanity really started to ask the question, “What about evil?”. From there we will be drilling into defining our terms and establishing the parameters for an answer. We’ll take a look at the six common solutions Christians give to explain evil as well as Christensen’s answer. We of course will be delving into Scripture to see who is God, who is Jesus is, why redemption and meta-narratives are important in the discussion, and the implications of everything.

And now you see the reason for the length of the book!

item.title: The Answer To Evil…Already? – Ep. 139 – What About Evil? – Introduction – Part 1
item.description:
The Answer To Evil…Already?

Scott Christensen takes the first part of the introduction to his book “What About Evil? A Defense of God’s Sovereign Glory” and does something interesting – he gives you the answer to evil at the start!

First, he presents the idea that there does, in fact, exist evil and suffering in the world and that it is one of the biggest arguments people cite against Christianity. The Christian worldview is not devoid of an answer to this and so the theodicy is laid out in response to people like Epicurus and David Hume.

We are presented with six main answers to the problem of evil from the Christian point of view:

1) The Free-Will Defense
2) Natural-Law Defense
3) Greater-Good Theodicy
4) Soul-Making Theodicy
5) Best-of-All-Possible-Worlds Defense
6) Divine-Judgment Defense

Christensen introduces these answers but also provides us his answer to the problem of evil. It is one that he believes is the most biblical, Reformed, and God-centered which should be the Christian’s focus. He gives a logical breakdown of his answer and sets up the rest of the book to follow.

item.title: TAG Christianity Is It – Ep. 138 – Dr. James Anderson Interview
item.description:
TAG! Christianity Is It!

We have the absolute pleasure of welcoming Dr. James Anderson to the show. We recently went through his book “Why Should I Believe Christianity” which was a presuppositional take on taking seriously the claims of the worldview of Christianity. We also said it was a good give-away book in that it was one you could give to someone asking questions about Christianity or someone who recently became a Christian. You can find all the episodes of that book on our website. TAG Christian Is It!

In the interview, we talk about Dr. Anderson’s background in computer programming and how that benefited his coming into the Christian apologetic field. We get a quick overview of the transcendental argument (TAG) and see two versions of it. We discuss the importance of transcendental arguments and how it is not a circular fallacy. We talk about his book and why Christianity being a coherent worldview is important when addressing the claims of The Bible. We also find out what he thinks of the current state of the Christian Church and what to look out for and how we are feast set on apologetics but famine set on utilizing what God has provided.

We thank Dr. Anderson for his ministry and his work as well as coming on the show and making a couple of theology book nerds’ day.

item.title: Prelude To Evil – Ep. 137 – What About Evil?
item.description:
Prelude To Evil

We introduce the next book we’re going over. The book is What About Evil? A Defense of God’s Sovereign Glory by Scott Christensen. In this episode, we just go over the prelude to evil.

From the Amazon description:

“Reconciling the existence of God and evil has been a long-standing conundrum in Christian theology, yet a philosophical approach–rather than a theological one–dominates the discussion. Turning to the Bible’s grand storyline, Scott Christensen examines how sin, evil, corruption, and death fit into the broad outlines of redemptive history. He argues that God’s ultimate end in creation is to magnify his glory to his image-bearers, most notably by defeating evil through the atoning work of Christ.”

We hope you’ll pick up the book and join us on one of the most cited issues people have with the Christian worldview. There are answers and like with all things it points us to the glory and majesty of the Triune God.

item.title: Prayer Help – Ep. 136 – Interview With A Pastor – Pastor Jim Li
item.description:
Prayer Help

This week we welcome Pastor Jim Li onto the show for some prayer help. Pastor Li pastors in California but is very active in teaching in the Asian churches. As a result, his identity will be hidden today. And with Tony on vacation, you’re stuck looking at Patrick. Good thing we make an audio-only version of the show.

Patrick invited Pastor Jim on to discuss prayer. As Patrick struggles with prayer, Pastor Jim was gracious enough to sit down and have a conversation about how to have a conversation with God. item.title: If Christianity’s True – Ep. 135 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – Defying Death & What Now?
item.description:
If Christianity’s True

We conclude Dr. James Anderson’s book by looking at what if Christianity’s true. We discuss alternative explanations to the Resurrection and see that they don’t rise to the occasion. Did Jesus swoon? Have His body stolen? By the disciples? By the Romans/Jewish leaders? Was it all an illusion? There are good reasons to believe Jesus was raised from the dead.

In the conclusion, we look at what to do now. We summarize what we looked at in the book and what we didn’t see in the book. Finally, if Christianity is true then we know that God still speaks but if salvation is a supernatural act why even write a book or tell others about Jesus? If Christianity is true then this is the most important message that answers the biggest worldview questions we have to answer.

item.title: Resurrection Proofs – Ep. 134 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – Defying Death – Part 1
item.description:
Resurrection Proofs

The ultimate moment in history for Christians is the Resurrection of Jesus Christ. If Christianity is true, this event is the most important event for every person who lived, living, or will ever live. Where do Resurrection proofs fit in the Christian worldview then?

Through the anticipation of Old Testament prophecy, the testimony of friends and foes that would become followers, and the actions of Jesus Himself we have a great confidence that the Resurrection took place just as The Bible describes it.

While not an exhaustive list of reasons, this does highlight some of the areas we can look at to show that Jesus was God and that when He died He rose again in fulfillment of the Scriptures for the payment of the sins of those who believe in Him.

Timeline Breakdown:

00:00 – Introduction
02:07 – The Afterlife In The Christian Worldview
04:35 – Why Christians Believe Jesus Rose From The Dead
06:26 – The Impossibilities Of Miracles
08:27 – Why Miracles Are Not Impossible
11:03 – Miracles Do Not Conflict With Science
15:24 – Probability Of Miracles
18:47 – Confidence Of Testimony
19:42 – An Event Not Plucked Out Of Nowhere
22:27 – Prophecies As Evidence
22:34 – Psalm 16:10
23:17 – Jesus’ Reputation & Prophecies
25:32 – Events Post-Jesus’ Death
26:31 – James, Jesus’ Half Brother
27:08 – Paul, The Persecutor
28:15 – The Multitude Of Witnesses
29:57 – Jesus’ Actions Point To His Foreknowledge Of His Upcoming Resurrection
33:53 – Conclusion

The episode link is cavetothecross.com/ep134

item.title: Jesus Is God – Ep. 133 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God With Us – Part 2
item.description:
Jesus Is God

After looking at the claims made by others about who Jesus is, we turn to Jesus and see what He says about Himself. We can conclude that Jesus is God by His own testimony and the events surrounding His life.

We look at Jesus accepting worship, approving the use of the title “Messiah”, calling Himself the Son of God, forgiving sins, associating Himself with the Father as one, living a perfect life, fulfilling prophecies, and culminating in rising from the dead.

While it may be difficult to conceive of Jesus being God it is not contradictory and, in fact, it is something we would want to see for the type of work by God that comes out of the Christian worldview and message.

item.title: Who Is Jesus? – Ep. 132 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God With Us – Part 1
item.description:
Who Is Jesus?

“Who is Jesus?” is a question that has not only been asked of by Christians and skeptics. That question is an important one to many other world religions, people seeking understanding, people of today and yesterday.

A big part of the Christian worldview revolves around the centrality of – Christ, Jesus. We cover what’s been said about Jesus according to the main sources and what that means that informs the Christian understanding of the world and the lens through which Christians should see through.

item.title: Old Testament Christianity – Ep. 131 – Interview With A Pastor – Dr. Tiberius Rata
item.description:
Old Testament Christianity

Is Old Testament Christianity an oxymoron or do we Christians still have a lot to learn from the Tanakh? Dr. Tiberius Rata is Associate Dean of the School of Ministry Studies and Professor of Old Testament Studies at Grace Theological Seminary. He is the author of several Old Testament commentaries as well.

Dr. Rata joins us to talk about what it was like growing up in communist Romania before coming to America and taking to the pulpit. Then we discuss the importance of the Old Testament and how should we as 21st century, Western Christians read and study it. Finally, we discuss the importance of apologetics he sees in seminary and what the future of apologetics looks like.

Plus, lots of book recommendations.

Timeline Breakdown:

00:00 – Introduction
01:32 – Growing Up As A Christian In Communist Romania
13:05 – From Urban Planner To Pastor
19:28 – What Is The Role Of The Old Testament For Christians Today?

35:58 – The Importance Of Understanding The Ancient Near East To Understand The Old Testament
40:03 – Learning From Jeremiah, Nehemiah, Ezra, & Ecclesiastes
45:57 – Is there still Old Testament scholarship work left to do?
49:34 – Apologetics Role In A Seminary Setting
54:18 – The Future Of Apologetics

item.title: Way, Truth, & Life – Ep. 130 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God Is Not Silent – Part 2
item.description:
Way, Truth, & Life

Christianity declares that it is the sole way, truth, & life. But it is not the only origin truth claim in town. Eastern religions, Islam, and Judaism are competing truth claims. They are all mutually exclusive – contradict each other and can’t all be true. So examining what we’ve covered so far, we see if Christianity or the other systems offered a better explanatory position that still coheres with itself. And of course, we cover everything in this 36-minute video fully and completely and answer all objections so that no one has anything left to say.  I’d say that’s enough to share, like, subscribe, and leave a review on your favorite podcast platform!

item.title: Written Bible – Ep. 129 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God Is Not Silent – Part 1
item.description:
Written Bible

A written Bible is expected and should be wanted. Following the logic that just as we are created beings who communicate in a personal way with language to convey information; we would expect the Creator God to also communicate in a personal way. So not only should we understand that something like the Bible is expected to come from this personal God but it’s also something we should desire out of all the different ways God can communicate to us.

13:32 – Language Is A Personal Interaction Relationship
17:03 – How God Speaks To Us
19:30 – An Object Way For God To Speak
21:17 – The Superiority Of The Written Format
21:59 – Conclusion

item.title: Youth And Apologetics – Ep. 128 – Interview With A Pastor – Justin McCoy
item.description:
Youth And Apologetics

Are today’s youth and apologetics connecting each other to answers and growth in their Christian faith? We welcome Youth Pastor Justin McCoy from Calvary Bible Church in Kalamazoo, MI. Pastor McCoy works with kids and students from birth through college. He gives his take on the role of seminary today and the preparation he had to lead the Christian youth today. He also discusses the role apologetics plays in his ministry. He also provides a message to parents, would-be parents, mentors, and those in the church without children.

item.title: Ep. 127 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God Is There – Part 3
item.description:
God Is There

God is there and there are things in the world that point to him. We finish the chapter covering how reason, the mind, and science all point to God’s existence. While atheists try and make themselves solely about science, we see their lack of grounding a bigger deal than they seem. As Dr. Mitch Stokes has said, “Many skeptics aren’t skeptical enough.” The skeptics that decry the trust Christians have display the blind faith in Nothing, the creator of everything, or some future explanation not yet seen.

item.title: Ep. 126 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – God Is There – Part 2
item.description:
Moral Meaning

Moral meaning values come up when we talk about politics, society, business practices, and other interactions between people and the world. However, when we say that the world isn’t as it should be or that we should do something or we ought not to do something, we are declaring that we believe there’s an idea of perfection to strive towards, the existence of objective value & standards, and objective morality. Where does that ideal and idea come from and which worldview actually accounts for it?

item.title: Ep. 125 – Why Should I Believe Christianity – God Is There – Part 1
item.description:
God Is There

God is real and there are real implications from that truth. When critics attempt to end the discussion of asking for proof that God is real they look for only one type of proof. What they look for is evidential, physical proof. But because of the nature of God, that’s the wrong evidence to ask for. Instead, one could look at one of the six reasons the biblical, Christian God must exist. In this episode, we cover the existence of existence for proof of God’s existence to exist.

item.title: Andreas Köstenberger Interview – Ep. 124 – Andreas Köstenberger Interview
item.description:
He’s Written On Everything!

We are beyond delighted and honored to sit down and interview Andreas Köstenberger. Dr. Köstenberger was a co-author in one of our recent chosen books, “Truth In A Culture Of Doubt” which was a response to many of Bart Ehrman’s writings and showing that Christianity provides answers to the critical historians’ claims. Dr. Köstenberger is also a prolific author of over 50 books. We talk about his work ethic, his life, and where he sees the direction of Christian scholarship going. I don’t know how we sat still for this interview!

Timeline Breakdown:

00:00 – Introduction
01:44 – How Does He Write So Much?!

26:15 – Bart Ehrman’s Two Audiences
29:02 – The Layout Of “Truth In A Culture Of Doubt”

item.title: Salvation – Ep. 123 – Why Should I Believe Christianity – Christianity As A Worldview – Part 3
item.description:
Salvation – The Relationship Of God & Man

Salvation is the third and final aspect of the Christian worldview to cover to set the stage for why one should believe Christianity. We see that God is able to speak and does speak to His creation. And what He says echoes in eternity.

Even while being the author of our salvation in His incarnation, atonement, and resurrection; God still works in relationship to us so that we might respond in faith and with repentance. He does so that all who will come to believe are drawn to Him.

We are to respond to His calling before the end of our world.

The Origin Of Original Sin

We go from perfect sinlessness to the original sin. But hey, at least we enter the picture finally! One of the things that all worldviews attempt to answer is, “Why are we here?” and “How are things the way they are?” The Christian worldview speaks to both of those things as well. There’s more to the story of course. However, you need to be able to know where you stand before you know which way to go.

item.title: Who Is God? – Ep. 121 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – Christianity As A Worldview – Part 1
item.description:
Who Is God?

Who is God? Since Christianity is a worldview, we have to understand what that worldview says and where it comes from. Both questions’ answers are found in the revealed nature of who is God. God has the ability and right to be the source of the revelation of Himself. It is found in the nature of Scripture we call The Bible. And we fly through all of Genesis 1:1 in this episode (and just a tad bit of the end of Genesis 1) to present qualities of the Christian worldview as grounded in the person, nature, and revelation of the God of the Bible.

item.description:
A Faith Test

Is it possible to put truth claims of a faith to a test? Dr. James Anderson showcases a four-fold test for seeing if the whole worldview system of a religion or belief system can be shown to be believable. Not only can this be done in isolation of another belief system but can be done with competing belief systems. A faith test is possible.

item.description:
Christianity As A Worldview

Everyone has a worldview but not everyone realizes it. When considering Christianity, breaking it up into its components allows critics to misconstrue the whole system of Christianity. Since Christianity is an entire worldview outlook, we must look at the belief system as the entire system in total lest we create straw men. But first, we must figure out what a worldview is and what it does for people.

item.title: Skepticism – Ep. 118 – Why Should I Believe Christianity – Introduction – Why Believe? – Part 2
item.description:
Skepticism As Default Approach?

Should we approach all claims with skepticism? While it seems like this is the smartest approach it’s not how we approach most truth claims.  So when it comes to Christianity we should have an understanding of our beliefs and our ability to know true things.  Finally, it’s important to understand that Christianity is more than just a series of events but that it entails a complete worldview and it should be approached as such.

item.title: Prove Christianity – Ep. 117 – Why Should I Believe Christianity? – Introduction – Why Believe?
item.description:
How Can I Prove Christianity?

If one were to go about trying to prove Christianity, how would one do that?  The first question to ask is really, “Why should anyone believe anything at all?”. In the introduction to James Anderson‘s book, we look at that and why believe Christianity in particular.  Is all truth relative?  How about religious claims?  Those seem to be particularly relative – or does our society try and dismiss them as such so we can get along?

item.title: Ep. 116 – Truth In A Culture Of Doubt – Reasons To Believe
item.description:
Rose From The Dead? Rose From The Dead!

Jesus rose from the dead. That’s the claim of The New Testament.

We close our book with a look at the response to this claim from Bart Ehrman’s challenges to it. Was Jesus even buried? Did the disciples hallucinate the resurrected Jesus? Did the disciples just make it up? The historic and archaeological evidence seems to better support Jesus’ death, burial, and resurrection than any alternative claim.

Then we end with a great challenge from Bart Ehrman himself!

item.title: Ep. 115 – Truth In A Culture Of Doubt – Are Many New Testament Documents Forged? – Part 3
item.description:
Apocryphal Books Of The Bible?

Are there lost, Apocryphal books that should have been included in The Bible? Finishing the chapter on how the New Testament should include the authentic books that are there, we look at why not other books.

  • Why do we include only the 27 books and not 12 others or Gnostic ones?
  • Why four Gospels and not six?
  • Why not include every book written?

If not everything, then clearly the Canon arises just from that fact alone. The Canon is not a stick used to beat other equal books away. It is a ruler used to show authentic teaching from those that weren’t.

item.title: Ep. 114 – Are Many New Testament Documents Forged? – Part 2
item.description:
Who Wrote The Bible?

Who wrote The Bible? The next two claims of forgery against the New Testament are the allegations of illiterate authors & false attribution to authors. Were the NT writers too illiterate to write their documents & couldn’t find another way to get their ideas down to be disseminated to others? Is there proof that the names of the authors were put onto the NT documents just to add some credibility to the forgeries? Once the evidence is evaluated, the claims of illiteracy & forgery crumble.

item.title: Ep. 113 – Are Many New Testament Documents Forged? – Part 1
item.description:
Fraud In The Bible?

Fraud in The Bible by the New Testament authors? Say it isn’t so! Not really. The claim that anonymous authors, centuries after the life of Christ and the apostles were the real authors of the Christian Scriptures is false. In fact, without a full-on skeptical presuppositional worldview, one could see just how amazing the New Testament manuscripts really are.

Timeline Breakdown:

03:55 – Treating Ehrman’s Writings Like Ehrman Treats The NT

Transcription

Introduction

Patrick: Hello, I’m Patrick.

Tony:  I’m Tony.

Patrick: Welcome back to the Cave To The Cross Apologetics, where we’re figuring out if we can find truth in this culture of doubt and we’re going over chapter five now of answering the question are many New Testament documents forged. And so, Bart Ehrman has a number of things critiques here of pretty much how the Bible can’t be what we think it is because certain characteristics of the authors, of the alleged authors, of the time of place of which everything took place. And then, still looking through the lens of Walter Bauer and his hypothesis that we started a little, or that we really looked at last chapter in chapter four. So yeah, I haven’t been there yet that was a good and fun chapter and something that needs to be responded to, because that tends to be because of the fame of Bart Ehrman he’s popularized the Bauer hypothesis. And so, you kind of see a lot of that stuff out there and in the ether, if you will. And a lot of people like Ehrman, so he’ll be getting a lot of those talking points.

5 Claims Of Proof Of NT Forgery
